data.text:
OM NA MA SI VA YA VAARGZHA

Introduction

From the dawn of history, mankind has believed in a Supreme Being, commonly referred to as ‘God’. This belief has resulted in the growth of many religions; each differing from the other due to how each perceives this God.

History of Religions

Nearly all of the religions of the world today can be traced to a period when they were founded and also establish their respective founders. Unlike most religions, one cannot establish a date for Saivism because it existed from pre-historic times and has no founder. Evidence found in the Indus Valley establishes the fact that Saivism is more than 5000 years old.

Scriptures

Mankind draws its spiritual inspiration and knowledge about God from Scriptures. Does Saivism have any scriptures? Most certainly! Of all the religions of India, Saivism has the largest volume of scriptures.

Saivism draws its inspiration from the Agamas and Vedas, both of which are written in Sanskrit. The Vedas are general in that they deal with many gods such as Varuna, Indra etc. and the various rituals performed for these gods. The Agamas, however, are special in that they deal with Siva Peruman alone.

Popular Scriptures in use by Saivites may be classified into two groups –‘Thothiram’(Devotional or Bakthi literature) and ‘Sasthiram’ or philosophy.

Devotional Works

Saivite Saints have sung in praise of Siva Peruman. These devotional outpourings are not only an expression of their Love, but contain valuable messages and deep insights into our religion. These devotional works are collectively known as the Thirumurais. There are 12 Thirumurais and they are numbered as follows:

Thirumuraigal 1 – 3 by Thirugnanasambandar

Thirumuraigal 4 – 6 by Thirunaavukarasar (Appar)

Thirumuraigal 7 by Sundramurthi Swamigal

NOTE: This is important. The above seven ‘Thirumurais’ are commonly referred to as the Thevaram.

Thirumurai 8: Thiruvasagam – St. Manikkavasagar

Thirumurai 9: Thiruvisaippa – Nine Saints

Thirumurai 10: Thirumandiram – Thirumoolar

Thirumurai 11: Collection of works by Karaikaalavaiyar and others

Thirumurai 12: Periyapuranam by Sekkizhaar

Philosophical Works

Unlike many religions of India, Saivism is fortunate to have a large volume of philosophical works. These works make intellectual an inquiry into the nature of God, Soul and the fetters (discussed later).

The fourteen philosophical works are:

Thiruvinthiyar -Thiruviyaloor* Uyavandha Devar

Thirukalirupadiyar – Thirukadvoor* Uyavandha Devar

Sivajnanabodham – Lord Meikandar

Sivajnaana Siddhiyar – Arulnandhi Sivaachiriyar

Irupa Irupathu – Arulnandhi Sivaachiriyar

Unmai Vilakkam – Manavaasagam Kadanthaar

Sivapirakaasam – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Thiruvarutpayan – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Vinaa Venba – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Porripahrodai – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Kodikar – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Nenju Vidu Thoothu – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Unmai Neri Vilakkam – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Sankarpa Neerakaaranam – Umapathi Sivaachaariyar

Later Saiva Devotional Works

Later Saiva Saints such as Thaaiyumaanavar, Arunagirinaathar, Sivajnana Munivar and Kumarkuruparar produced works of exceptional quality.
